title: The Scientific Method
objectives: Understand the steps of the scientific method: observation, hypothesis, experimentation, data analysis, and conclusion.
Differentiate between independent, dependent, and controlled variables in an experiment.
Develop testable hypotheses and design basic experiments.
Analyze and interpret data to draw logical conclusions.
Distinguish between scientific theory and law.
Apply scientific thinking to real-world problems and case studies.

title: Cells: The Basic Unit of Life
objectives: Identify the structure and function of major cell organelles (e.g., nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes).
Compare and contrast prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
Understand the differences between plant and animal cells.
Explain the processes of cell membrane transport: diffusion, osmosis, and active transport.
Introduce cell theory and its historical development.
Describe how cells reproduce through mitosis and cytokinesis.

title: Photosynthesis: Capturing Light Energy
objectives: Define photosynthesis and explain its importance in the energy cycle.
Identify the main structures involved in photosynthesis, especially chloroplasts.
Write the balanced chemical equation for photosynthesis.
Explain the role of light, water, and carbon dioxide in the process.
Differentiate between light-dependent and light-independent (Calvin cycle) reactions.
Understand how environmental factors affect the rate of photosynthesis.

title: Genetics and Heredity
objectives: Understand the basic principles of inheritance introduced by Gregor Mendel.
Explain the function of DNA, genes, and chromosomes in heredity.
Interpret Punnett squares to predict genetic outcomes.
Differentiate between dominant and recessive traits.
Explore real-world examples of inherited traits and genetic disorders.
Understand the basics of meiosis and its role in genetic variation.

title: Ecosystems and Biodiversity
objectives: Define ecosystems and describe their components: biotic and abiotic factors.
Explain energy flow through food chains and food webs.
Describe the roles of producers, consumers, and decomposers.
Understand ecological relationships: competition, predation, symbiosis.
Explain the importance of biodiversity to ecosystem stability and human life.
Discuss threats to biodiversity and conservation efforts globally and locally.
